population_specificity: Individuals with obesity, including those with and without diabetes.
study_duration: Relatively short periods (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits and barriers of bariatric surgery for kidney transplant candidates and recipients with sarcopenic obesity.
results_summary: The study suggests bariatric surgery shows promising benefits for improving kidney transplant access in obese candidates but emphasizes the need for careful patient selection. It also highlights the interconnected management of sarcopenia and obesity, noting the obesity paradox in dialysis-dependent patients.
population_specificity: Kidney transplant waitlisted candidates and recipients, as well as potential living kidney donors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the current landscape and available literature on the use of antiobesity pharmacotherapy in children, including the role of bariatric surgery as an effective treatment for severe pediatric obesity.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgery is currently the most effective obesity treatment but has limited utilization in pediatric cases, primarily reserved for children with worsening comorbidities. It also notes a significant treatment gap for pediatric obesity after lifestyle modifications fail, with pharmacotherapy being underutilized despite emerging data on its efficacy.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with obesity, particularly those with severe or worsening comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of transcatheter bariatric embolotherapy (TBE) of the left gastric artery for promoting weight loss in obese subjects compared to a sham procedure.
results_summary: The study found that TBE was well-tolerated and resulted in clinically significant weight loss compared to the sham procedure, with a mean excess weight loss of 8.2% in the TBE group versus 1.5% in the sham group at 6 months.
population_specificity: Obese subjects (BMI 35 to 55 kg/m², mean BMI 39.6 ± 3.8 kg/m²; age 45.5 ± 9.4 years; 8 men/36 women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the current integrated clinical pathway for obesity management in England, focusing on challenges related to access, treatment flexibility, and efficacy, including bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that access to bariatric surgery is limited, with major barriers including rigid pathways, uncertain treatment outcomes, and weight stigma. It emphasized the need for improved access, personalized care, and long-term health outcome evaluations.
population_specificity: Obesity management pathways in England, including patients eligible for tier 4 (bariatric surgery) treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the analgesic efficacy of propofol TIVA compared to inhalational anesthesia in reducing postoperative pain and opioid consumption, including in bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Propofol TIVA was associated with reduced postoperative pain scores and/or decreased opioid consumption in 9 out of 16 clinical trials, though results varied by surgical procedure. For bariatric surgery specifically, the abstract does not provide separate results, but it was included among the procedures studied.
population_specificity: Adult patients undergoing various surgical procedures, including bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LGBP) combined with lifestyle intervention is a safe and effective treatment for adolescents with morbid obesity.
results_summary: The study found that gastric bypass led to significant weight loss (30%) compared to lifestyle intervention alone (1% weight gain) and improved cardiometabolic risk factors, but some patients experienced minor complications and nutritional deficiencies.
population_specificity: Adolescents with morbid obesity (average age 16.7 years in surgery group, 15.6 years in control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preoperative cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) enhances long-term weight loss and psychological outcomes in bariatric surgery patients compared to treatment-as-usual (TAU).
results_summary: Preoperative CBT showed short-term improvements in eating behavior and psychological symptoms from pretreatment to posttreatment/pre-surgery, but no significant long-term benefits were observed at 1-year post-surgery compared to TAU. The study concluded that preoperative CBT does not contribute to better long-term outcomes post-surgery.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery in a multi-center randomized controlled trial.
effective_dosage: 10 individual, weekly sessions of preoperative CBT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how digital interventions support health behavior changes (e.g., physical activity, weight loss, dietary intake, psychological support) in patients undergoing elective surgeries, including bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Digital interventions were found to motivate health behavior change, improve patient engagement, facilitate peer networking, and meet individualized needs, though only 2 of the 18 studies focused specifically on bariatric surgery. Self-regulatory features and personalized content were positively received, suggesting potential benefits for bariatric patients.
population_specificity: Adult patients undergoing elective surgeries (bariatric, cancer, orthopedic).

study_goal: To develop clinical guidelines for G-tube placement in the remnant stomach as a treatment for severe, refractory hypoglycemia after RYGB.
results_summary: The study found that enteral nutrition via G-tube in the remnant stomach effectively reverses hyperinsulinemia and hypoglycemia, improving health and quality of life for severely affected patients. A team-based approach is recommended for candidate selection, preoperative evaluation, and postoperative management.
population_specificity: Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) patients with severe hypoglycemia refractory to medical-nutrition therapy and significantly affected quality of life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess changes in weight and body composition in patients undergoing One Anastomosis Gastric Bypass (OAGB) bariatric surgery during the first postoperative year.
results_summary: The study analyzed 405 patients and found significant changes in weight and body composition following OAGB surgery over the first year post-operation.
population_specificity: 405 patients (68.9% women, 31.1% men), mean age 44 years, mean weight 110.02 kg, BMI 39.76 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the morphometric characteristics of collagen and elastic fibers in the skin of patients who had massive weight loss following bariatric surgery compared to those with morbid obesity.
results_summary: The study found that massive weight loss after bariatric surgery led to reduced thick collagen fibers, increased thin collagen fibers, and higher elastic fiber density, indicating collagenous remodeling and improved skin elasticity. No differences were observed in mean age or total collagen fiber amount between the groups.
population_specificity: 20 patients with massive weight loss post-bariatric surgery and 20 patients with morbid obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if 12-week protein supplementation was effective and tolerable for increasing protein intake in bariatric surgery patients and to evaluate its effects on body composition, metabolic rate, and functional outcomes.
results_summary: About 80% of patients achieved the recommended 60g protein intake daily, with protein supplementation helping increase intake. Both groups saw significant weight, BMI, and body composition reductions, though results varied by measurement method.
population_specificity: Bariatric surgery patients (n=49, 88% female, mean age 43.7±10.7 years, BMI 51.2±13.7 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the perioperative clinical results of systematic alveolar recruitment manoeuvre combined with protective ventilation in obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The recruitment manoeuvre group had significantly lower rates of pulmonary dysfunction in the recovery room (73% vs. 84%) and at postoperative day 1 (77% vs. 88%) compared to the control group. No significant differences were found for secondary outcomes, and the manoeuvre was well-tolerated.
population_specificity: Obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
study_duration: Perioperative period (immediate recovery room and postoperative day 1)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate recent experimental evidence on gut microbiota alterations following bariatric surgery, focusing on sleeve gastrectomy and gastric bypass.
results_summary: The study highlights that gut microbiota composition and function are significantly altered after bariatric surgery, which may contribute to metabolic regulation in obese patients. These changes could inform new therapeutic strategies for metabolic syndrome and related disorders.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity undergoing bariatric surgery (sleeve gastrectomy or gastric bypass).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify novel gut-derived peptides with therapeutic potential in obesity and/or diabetes by profiling enteroendocrine cell-specific molecular changes in obese patients following Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB)-induced weight loss.
results_summary: RYGB increased expression of liver-expressed antimicrobial peptide 2 (LEAP2), and its fragment LEAP238-47 demonstrated strong insulinotropic effects in vitro but no glucoregulatory effects in healthy human subjects. The insulinotropic action may be linked to attenuation of growth hormone secretagogue receptor (GHSR) activity.
population_specificity: 20 obese subjects who underwent RYGB and 10 healthy human individuals.
effective_dosage: Not specified for RYGB; LEAP238-47 fragment was infused in healthy subjects (dose not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified for RYGB; LEAP238-47 infusion duration not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pathogenesis, risk factors, prevention, and treatment of gastric sleeve leaks, with a focus on endoscopic approaches, and assess the efficacy of different treatment modalities.
results_summary: Endoscopic management of leaks post sleeve gastrectomy is minimally invasive and effective, with success rates depending on provider expertise. Surgical intervention is necessary for shock or peritonitis, while chronic leaks require a combination of endoscopic, radiologic, or surgical approaches.
population_specificity: Patients with gastric sleeve leaks post bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether weight loss induced by bariatric surgery could delay or reverse mental deterioration in patients with obesity and chronic traumatic brain injury (TBI).
results_summary: The study suggests that bariatric surgery improves metabolic efficiency, reverses brain lesions, and enhances function, potentially making it an effective therapy for TBI-related mental deterioration.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity and chronic traumatic brain injury (TBI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between adipose tissue senescence and metabolic complications in severely obese individuals, and whether bariatric surgery improves these complications regardless of initial adipose tissue senescent status.
results_summary: The study found that subcutaneous adipose tissue senescence was linked to metabolic complications like insulin resistance and dyslipidemia, but bariatric surgery improved these conditions irrespective of initial senescence levels. Senolytic treatment reduced senescence markers and normalized metabolic alterations in adipose tissue.
population_specificity: 227 individuals with severe obesity undergoing gastric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether preoperative executive function, particularly inhibitory control, predicts weight loss one year after bariatric surgery and explore the mediating role of postoperative compulsive grazing.
results_summary: Preoperative inhibitory control explained 8% of the variance in weight loss, while working memory did not. Postoperative compulsive grazing was significantly associated with weight loss but did not mediate the relationship between inhibitory control and weight loss.
population_specificity: 80% female, average age 41 years, undergoing gastric bypass (54%), gastric sleeve (26%), or one anastomosis gastric bypass (20%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of GLP-1 in taste perception, particularly sweet perception, and whether GLP-1-based therapies, including bariatric surgery, could modulate gustatory coding and food preferences.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is associated with diminished appreciation of sweet food, suggesting a potential link between GLP-1 and altered taste perception post-surgery. However, the modulatory potential of GLP-1 receptor agonists in gustatory coding remains unknown.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on mammalian gustatory system, with implications for aging, diabetes, and obesity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish the optimal diagnostic and treatment algorithm for managing gastric fistula in the chest (GFIC) after sleeve gastrectomy (SG).
results_summary: The study found that GFIC after SG was diagnosed using CT scans combined with UGI series or EGD, and initial treatment involved endoscopic clips and stents, with surgical intervention (total gastrectomy and Roux-en-Y esophagojejunostomy) required in most cases when endoscopic methods failed.
population_specificity: Patients with gastric fistula in the chest after sleeve gastrectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exercise training could enhance the benefits of bariatric surgery on cardiac autonomic regulation in post-bariatric patients.
results_summary: The study found that a 6-month exercise training program significantly improved chronotropic response to exercise and heart rate recovery in women who underwent bariatric surgery compared to those who did not exercise. These results suggest that exercise enhances the cardiovascular benefits of bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: Sixty-two women eligible for bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a post-operative exercise-based educational and motivational program on improving behaviors, quality of life, and physical outcomes in bariatric patients compared to surgical intervention alone.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in behavioral and physical outcomes, including quality of life and physical fitness, while the control group exhibited lesser changes. The results suggest that a multidisciplinary postoperative program may enhance surgery outcomes.
population_specificity: Adult sedentary bariatric patients (85.7% females in the intervention group, 71.4% females in the control group, mean age ~38-40 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current studies evaluating changes in microRNA expression in obese patients undergoing lifestyle interventions or bariatric surgery to identify potential biomarkers for weight loss and response to interventions.
results_summary: The review found differential expression of circulating microRNAs before and after dietary and bariatric surgery interventions, identifying candidate biomarkers of response to weight loss. Significant changes in microRNA expression were observed in different adipose tissues, with distinct patterns between responders and non-responders.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese patients undergoing lifestyle interventions or bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically discuss the role of obesity as a secondary cause of hypertension and evaluate the impact of weight loss therapies like bariatric surgery on hypertension remission.
results_summary: The study highlights that obesity, if accepted as a secondary cause of hypertension, could be the most common cause due to the significant impact of weight loss therapies such as bariatric surgery on hypertension remission, unlike other common secondary causes like OSA or chronic kidney disease.
population_specificity: Patients with resistant hypertension, particularly those with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review care management and new therapeutic opportunities, including bariatric surgery, for genetic obesity, focusing on syndromic and monogenic forms.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that bariatric surgery has been undertaken in genetic obesity cases with uncertain outcomes, indicating mixed or inconclusive efficacy. New therapies, such as setmelanotide, are being tested, suggesting a shift away from reliance on surgery alone.
population_specificity: Patients with severe genetic obesity, including syndromic and monogenic forms, often with neurodevelopmental or psychiatric disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze factors influencing adherence to multivitamin supplementation (MVS) after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study highlights that while bariatric surgery is effective for long-term weight loss and improving obesity-related co-morbidities, vitamin deficiencies are common post-surgery, and patient adherence to MVS is generally poor. The review discusses factors affecting MVS use in bariatric surgery patients and compares findings with other patient groups.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bariatric surgery and other patient groups requiring MVS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of intragastric botulinum toxin A on weight loss, satiety, biomarkers, and quality of life in obese patients awaiting bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The treatment group showed significant weight loss compared to the control group at all measured time points (up to 24 weeks) and reported improved quality of life, particularly in subjective physical capacity. No significant differences were found in satiety perception or biomarkers of satiety and appetite.
population_specificity: 52 obese patients on bariatric surgery waiting lists.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of full-time telemedicine adoption on patient visit volume and attendance in a multidisciplinary metabolic and weight loss center.
results_summary: New patient visits decreased overall, with surgeons experiencing a 75% drop, while follow-up visits increased for certain nonsurgical providers (e.g., advanced practitioners saw a 27.36% increase). Dietitians had higher absenteeism for new visits, whereas bariatricians saw reduced absenteeism for follow-ups.
population_specificity: Patients attending a comprehensive metabolic and weight loss center during the COVID-19 pandemic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of ultrasound-guided transversus abdominis plane (USG-TAP) block as part of multimodal analgesia in laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that USG-TAP block significantly reduced pain scores and opioid requirements, shortened time to ambulation, and had minimal reported complications. Pooled analysis supported its incorporation into Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS) protocols for bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery (525 participants across eight studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and risks of bariatric surgery in patients with type 1 diabetes, focusing on weight loss, glycemic control, and prevention of complications.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was associated with significant long-term reductions in daily insulin requirements and body mass index, as well as improvements in obesity-related comorbidities like hypertension and dyslipidemia. However, glycemic control improvements were modest or insignificant, and safety concerns included metabolic complications such as diabetic ketoacidosis and severe hypoglycemia.
population_specificity: Patients with type 1 diabetes and obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bariatric surgery in managing obesity-related conditions, particularly chronic kidney disease (CKD), and its potential benefits for kidney function and transplantation outcomes.
results_summary: Observational studies suggest bariatric surgery reduces the risk of estimated glomerular filtration rate decline and kidney failure, improves access to kidney transplantation, and leads to favorable posttransplantation outcomes. However, uncertainty remains due to the lack of prospective trials and limitations of observational data.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity, type 2 diabetes, and CKD, including those with kidney failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how bariatric surgery-induced weight loss impacts IVF outcomes in obese infertile women compared to non-operated women of similar or higher BMI.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in cumulative live birth rates between women with a history of bariatric surgery and non-operated women of similar BMI, though severely obese non-operated women had lower live birth rates. Miscarriage rates and newborn weight differences were noted but not statistically significant in all comparisons.
population_specificity: Obese infertile women undergoing IVF, including those with a history of bariatric surgery (mean BMI 28.9 kg/m²), non-operated women with similar BMI (28.8 kg/m²), and severely obese non-operated women (37.7 kg/m²).
study_duration: Retrospective analysis of IVF cycles performed between 2012 and 2016.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of probiotic supplementation on weight change, quality of life, gastrointestinal symptoms, and adverse events in patients with morbid obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Probiotics showed minor to no effect on percentage excess weight loss at various follow-up periods but provided short-term improvement in gastrointestinal symptoms. No meaningful adverse events or significant effects on quality of life were observed.
population_specificity: Patients with morbid obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.
study_duration: Follow-up periods ranged from 6 weeks to 12 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the 30-year risk for cardiovascular disease (CVD) events in adolescents with type 2 diabetes (T2D) and severe obesity undergoing either medical treatment or metabolic bariatric surgery (MBS).
results_summary: The study found that MBS reduced the estimated 30-year CVD event risk in adolescents with T2D and severe obesity, whereas medical therapy was associated with an increased risk. Despite higher pretreatment CVD risk in the surgical group, MBS showed a beneficial effect.
population_specificity: Adolescents with T2D and severe obesity (mean age 16.9 ± 1.3 years, 70% female, 60% white, BMI 54.4 ± 9.5 kg/m²).

study_goal: To assess the effect of family member attendance at routine pre- and postoperative appointments on patients' weight loss, physical activity levels, and family members' weight control practices.
results_summary: Family member attendance at appointments had no significant effect on patient outcomes but showed positive effects on family members' self-monitoring, physical activity, and psychological control practices. No significant differences were found in weight control practices between the intervention and control groups.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery and their romantic partners or cohabitating family members.
study_duration: From pre-surgery class (T1) to 2 months post-surgery (T4)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal type and timing of achalasia intervention in bariatric surgery patients and compare treatment responses between those diagnosed before versus after surgery.
results_summary: Patients treated for achalasia before bariatric surgery had better symptom resolution, while those diagnosed after surgery experienced more recurrent dysphagia. LHM was the most common procedure but had higher recurrence rates in post-bariatric surgery patients.
population_specificity: 13 bariatric surgery patients diagnosed with achalasia at a single academic institution (2012–2019).
study_duration: Variable (achalasia diagnosed up to 8.3 years post-bariatric surgery).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the available literature on preoperative nutritional assessment, preparation, and education for patients planning to undergo bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that proper preoperative management should include comprehensive nutritional assessment and individualized preparation strategies, but more well-designed studies are needed to establish uniform guidelines. Current evidence supports the importance of nutritional interventions, though long-term outcomes of these programs require further research.
population_specificity: Patients planning to undergo bariatric surgery, including those at higher nutritional risk.

study_goal: To compare the noninferiority of pressure-controlled ventilation (PCV) versus volume-controlled ventilation (VCV) in respiratory mechanics during laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
results_summary: PCV was noninferior to VCV, with 97% success in sustaining adequate ventilation compared to 94% for VCV. Peak airway pressure increased slightly in PCV but remained within acceptable limits.
population_specificity: 66 individuals with morbid obesity undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgeries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of perioperative behavioral lifestyle or nutritional interventions in enhancing long-term weight change outcomes following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Low to very-low certainty evidence suggests that certain interventions (physical activity, nonvitamin nutritional interventions, vitamins, psychotherapy, and counseling) may provide short-term benefits (up to 12 months), but results were not statistically significant except for counseling at 12 months. Psychotherapy and counseling showed potential benefits at longer follow-ups (>12 months), but evidence quality was low and based on small sample sizes.
population_specificity: People with morbid obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.
study_duration: Follow-ups ranged up to 12 months and beyond.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors contributing to variability in weight loss outcomes from obesity treatments, including bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that individual responses to bariatric surgery vary due to factors like genetics, neurohormonal mechanisms, metabolic efficiency, and gut microbiome, beyond known influences like diet adherence and physical activity.
population_specificity: Humans with obesity (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare mid-term outcomes of laparoscopic bariatric surgery between elderly patients (age >60) and young patients (age ≤60).
results_summary: Elderly patients had higher overall morbidity and specific post-operative complications after LSG compared to young patients, but outcomes were similar after LRYGB. Weight loss was achieved in both groups but was statistically greater in young patients.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (>60 years) and young patients (≤60 years) undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of percutaneous embolization with fluoroscopy-visible glue as a non-invasive method to treat subacute gastric fistula after laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG).
results_summary: The study found that percutaneous fibrinogen-thrombin embolization (PFTE) can effectively treat subacute gastric fistula after LSG, with fluoroscopy-visible glue enabling precise sealing of the fistula tract and avoiding complications from gas inflation during endoscopic intervention.
population_specificity: A 23-year-old woman with a BMI of 35.7 kg/m² who developed a subacute gastric fistula after LSG.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of abdominal CT in identifying postoperative complications of bariatric surgery and to analyze the most illustrative tomographic findings in patients who underwent reducing gastroplasty.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is effective for weight loss and reducing comorbidities, but complications such as fistulas, dehiscence, and intestinal obstruction can occur. Abdominal CT was identified as a crucial tool for diagnosing these complications postoperatively.
population_specificity: 203 patients who underwent reducing gastroplasty, with no distinction of age or gender.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent evidence on treating metabolic syndrome in children and adolescents, including the role of bariatric surgery in preventing metabolic and cardiovascular complications.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that bariatric surgery may be useful in selected cases for preventing metabolic and cardiovascular complications in children and adolescents with metabolic syndrome, alongside lifestyle interventions and pharmacological treatments.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of bariatric surgery in improving erectile function and overall sexual function in obese males.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found significant improvements in IIEF and BSFI scores across multiple domains of sexual function, including erectile function, intercourse satisfaction, orgasmic function, and sexual desire, following bariatric surgery. The results suggest bariatric surgery is effective in enhancing male sexual function in obese individuals.
population_specificity: Obese males

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of a magnetic surgical system for liver retraction in bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that the magnetic surgical system was well-tolerated and effective for liver retraction in minimally invasive bariatric surgery across a range of body mass indexes. Patient follow-up at 7 and 30 days postprocedure supported its safety and efficacy.
population_specificity: 50 patients with a body mass index ranging from 28.4 to 58.2 kg/m² undergoing bariatric procedures at two investigational sites in Chile.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an algorithm for evaluating and managing pancreatic rest (PR) found during screening endoscopies prior to bariatric surgery.
results_summary: PR is often found incidentally in the gastric antrum, with larger lesions posing higher risks of symptoms or malignancy. Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) aids in diagnosis and resection planning, with resection method depending on lesion size, depth, and endoscopist skill.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing screening endoscopies prior to bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of GLP-1R agonists and other co-agonists with bariatric surgery for treating metabolic disorders like diabetes and obesity.
results_summary: The study found that current GLP-1R agonists are not yet as effective as bariatric surgery, but emerging co-agonists like tirzepatide and amylin combinations show promising clinical efficacy. Increasing doses of GLP-1R agonists, such as semaglutide, also produce substantial weight loss, setting a higher benchmark for new therapies.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes, obesity, and related cardiometabolic disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine clinical correlates of food addiction in post-operative bariatric surgery patients and assess the effectiveness of a brief Tele-CBT intervention on food addiction symptoms.
results_summary: The study compared clinical characteristics of patients with and without food addiction and evaluated whether Tele-CBT improved food addiction symptoms, but specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Post-operative bariatric surgery patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to outline nutrient deficiencies resulting from bariatric procedures and report recommendations for screening and treatment.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery can lead to nutritional deficiencies, particularly vitamin D, calcium, vitamin B12, and iron, necessitating baseline testing, postoperative screening, and higher-dose supplementation. Complications vary by procedure type, with malabsorptive procedures posing higher risks.
population_specificity: Patients with morbid obesity who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current evidence on how bariatric surgery alleviates insulin resistance in type 2 diabetes mellitus by altering the gut microbiome and microbial metabolites.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery significantly alleviates insulin resistance, likely through changes in gut microbiome composition and microbial metabolites such as lipopolysaccharides, short-chain fatty acids, and bile acids. The mechanisms linking these changes to postoperative improvements in insulin resistance were discussed but not fully elucidated.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of combining robotic sleeve gastrectomy with robotic-assisted kidney transplant versus robotic kidney transplant alone in patients with class II or III obesity.
results_summary: The study found that combined robotic sleeve gastrectomy and kidney transplant resulted in significant BMI reduction (-8.76 vs. +1.70) without differences in graft function, readmission, or complication rates, though surgery duration was longer. Both approaches showed similar safety profiles.
population_specificity: Patients with class II or III obesity awaiting kidney transplantation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness and applicability of endobariatric therapies (EBTs) as less invasive alternatives to bariatric surgery for patients with mild to moderate obesity.
results_summary: The study highlights that endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty and primary obesity surgery endoluminal are promising EBTs, mimicking bariatric surgery effects with high efficacy and broader applicability. These therapies are less invasive and suitable for patients who may not qualify for traditional bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with mild to moderate obesity eligible for bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an educational intervention (booklet vs. verbal guidance) in improving knowledge and attitudes of preoperative bariatric surgery candidates.
results_summary: The booklet-mediated educational intervention significantly improved knowledge scores (31.1 ± 2.96) compared to verbal guidance (19.5 ± 6.17), with a statistically significant difference (p=0.000). Attitudes were generally adequate, particularly regarding vitamin intake, hydration, and physical activity.
population_specificity: 56 preoperative bariatric surgery patients (28 in intervention group, 28 in control group).
effective_dosage: Not specified (educational intervention via booklet or verbal guidance).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bariatric surgery in reducing the prevalence and severity of lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in morbidly obese men.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery significantly reduced body mass index and alleviated LUTS severity in morbidly obese men, with durable effects observed up to 3 years post-surgery. Follow-up rates were high, supporting the intervention's effectiveness.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese men (mean age 43.0 ± 10.4 years) undergoing sleeve gastrectomy or Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the risk of lithium toxicity in psychiatric patients undergoing bariatric surgery and propose preventive measures.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery can significantly alter lithium absorption, increasing the risk of toxicity. It recommends regular postoperative monitoring of lithium levels to prevent adverse effects.
population_specificity: Psychiatric patients (specifically a 44-year-old female case and a review of similar cases) undergoing bariatric surgery.
interactions: Lithium toxicity risk post-bariatric surgery due to altered absorption.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of delaying bariatric surgery during the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic and provide recommendations for safe resumption of surgery.
results_summary: The study highlights that delaying bariatric surgery can lead to new comorbidities in 50% of patients and a 1.5% mortality rate while on the waiting list. It recommends resuming surgery when hospital COVID-19 occupancy decreases and sufficient safety measures are in place.
population_specificity: Patients on bariatric surgery waiting lists in Spain during the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the magnitude of change in lipid parameters associated with weight loss in adults who are overweight or obese, specifically comparing lifestyle, pharmacologic, and bariatric surgery interventions.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was associated with reduced triglycerides (-2.47 mg/dL per 1 kg weight lost) and LDL-C (-0.33 mg/dL per 1 kg weight lost), and increased HDL-C (0.42 mg/dL per 1 kg weight lost) at 12 months. Results were consistent across malabsorptive and restrictive surgery types.
population_specificity: Adults who are overweight or obese (mean age 48.1 years, weight 101.6 kg, BMI 36.3 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of gut microbiota and butyrate in modulating brain dopamine and serotonin transporters via the gut-brain axis in obese metabolic syndrome patients post-RYGB surgery.
results_summary: FMT from post-RYGB donors increased brain DAT compared to oral butyrate, which reduced DAT binding. No significant effects on body weight or insulin sensitivity were observed, but changes in specific gut bacteria and plasma metabolites were linked to altered DAT expression.
population_specificity: Human subjects with obese metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of bariatric surgery in metabolically healthy obese (MHO) patients compared to non-MHO patients.
results_summary: MHO patients showed significantly higher total weight loss (%TWL) at two and three years post-surgery compared to non-MHO patients, with no differences in acute complications between the groups.
population_specificity: Metabolically healthy obese (MHO) patients without diabetes or atherogenic dyslipidemia, aged 48.97 ± 10.32 years, 68.6% female.
study_duration: Follow-up at two and three years post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high LDL cholesterol levels before surgery could influence the choice between gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy and to compare 1-year remission rates of high LDL cholesterol between the two procedures.
results_summary: The study will compare LDL cholesterol remission rates between gastric bypass and sleeve gastrectomy over 12 months, along with examining changes in other lipoproteins and LDL composition, and investigating pathophysiologic mechanisms related to LDL cholesterol remission.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18-60 with a body mass index ≥40 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify phenotypes or sub-groups of bariatric surgery patients requiring psychological support for sustainable weight loss and to review findings related to the Clinical Obesity Maintenance Model (COMM) constructs.
results_summary: The study highlights the need for personalized psychological interventions to improve long-term weight loss outcomes post-bariatric surgery, emphasizing factors like habit, emotion dysregulation, and executive function. It also proposes a framework (COMM) to guide assessment and follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing or considering bariatric surgery, particularly those at risk of weight recidivism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of perioperative music interventions on postoperative pain in abdominal surgery patients.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a significant positive impact of music on postoperative pain (p < 0.001), with half of the reviewed studies supporting this conclusion. No notable differences were observed between intra- and postoperative interventions or music selection methods.
population_specificity: Abdominal surgery patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of bariatric surgery as a non-pharmacological approach for reversing hypertensive left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH).
results_summary: The abstract suggests that bariatric surgery holds promise for LVH regression, but longitudinal studies assessing its impact on clinical outcomes are needed. No specific results on efficacy or safety are provided.
population_specificity: High-risk phenotypes, including blacks, women, and those with malignant LVH, were mentioned as potential beneficiaries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the expression of four candidate biomarkers (PNPLA3, COL1A1, PPP1R3B, and KLF6) in obese patients who underwent bariatric surgery to assess their potential applicability in classifying and treating NAFLD.
results_summary: The study found significantly increased levels of COL1A1 and PNPLA3 proteins in patients with fibrosis-stage NAFLD compared to those with steatosis-stage NAFLD, suggesting their potential as biomarkers for advanced NAFLD. No significant differences were observed for PPP1R3B and KLF6 proteins or at the gene level for any candidate.
population_specificity: 26 obese subjects who underwent bariatric surgery in the Saudi population.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between bariatric surgery and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), focusing on its potential to improve or worsen GERD, particularly after sleeve gastrectomy.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery can effectively improve GERD in many obese patients but may also worsen or cause new-onset GERD, especially after sleeve gastrectomy. Contributing factors include anatomical and physiological changes, with treatment options ranging from lifestyle changes to revisional surgery.
population_specificity: Obese individuals, particularly those who have undergone sleeve gastrectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing literature on the risk of developing alcohol use disorder (AUD) after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery and identify potential risk factors and mechanisms.
results_summary: The review found an increased risk of AUD after gastric bypass surgery, with identified risk factors including male sex, younger age, smoking, and pre-existing alcohol use. Altered alcohol metabolism and gut hormones may contribute to this risk, though the addiction transfer hypothesis remains controversial.
population_specificity: Individuals who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of gastric bypass versus sleeve gastrectomy in improving transient hepatic elastography (THE) and controlled attenuation parameter (CAP) values in patients with obesity and NAFLD.
results_summary: Sleeve gastrectomy showed a significantly greater decrease in THE and CAP values compared to gastric bypass, indicating better improvement in liver stiffness and steatosis within the first three months post-surgery. The differences were statistically significant for both parameters.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity and nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
